ygData.subject: Re: Interesting notes on evolving CTRNN substrates with HyperNEAT(fitness zero?)
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Ken, The fitness function used in the binary is Average_Head_Height * Number_of_FootSteps_Taken. The second multiplier rewards individuals that tend to walk

Hi Ken, 

The fitness function used in the binary is Average_Head_Height * =

Number_of_FootSteps_Taken. The second multiplier rewards individuals 
that=
 tend to walk around instead of staying still. I know it is maybe 
wrong to=
 assign 0.000 fitness, but I usually hope that in early 
generations at lea=
st some individuals will get a score above zero, 
and therefore survive. Is=
 this a right thing to do or I should 
translate all fitnesses above 0.000 =
? Like Total_Fitness +=3D 1.0; ? 
The Number_of_FootSteps_Taken is actually=
 an integer and it makes the 
fitness landscape look like stairs... This is=
 not good, but I can't 
think of another way to encourage walking around.. =
Rewarding cyclic 
activity in the output neurons didn't help me much.. It i=
s the same 
thing. 

I am experimenting with a lot of fitness functions eve=
ry day. The 
best individual I got for the balancing task was actually the =
same as 
the one found using regular NEAT - just standing. A way to prevent=
 
this is may be to choose random initial positions for the model.. Or 
the=
 ground plane can be made moving randomly.. 
Anyway, it seems that the fitn=
ess function is wrong, since this way 
of achieving the goal is too easy fo=
r the evolution to find.

I am currently trying out how good are they to wa=
lk. I replaced the 
Average_Head_Height with Total_Distance_Travelled in th=
e fitness 
function. 

I believe that HyperNEAT is able to handle such comp=
lex dynamic 
control tasks, given the right substrate geometry. Results so =
far do 
not show a big progress. But there are a lot of parameters to tweak=
 
and play with. Substrate configurations also. 

Ken, what about the sourc=
e code, can you compile it?  

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth=
 Stanley" <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Peter,
> 
> What is your fitness functi=
on in this domain?  Sometimes it looks 
> like individuals are assigned a f=
itness of 0.00000 yet when I look 
at 
> them it looked like they were bala=
nced for a while.  What is 
causing 
> them to get zero fitness?
> 
> Of co=
urse the fitness function in this domain can be tricky since 
> what you wa=
nt to encourage is balance, which is not necesarily 
always 
> correlated t=
o duration standing (e.g. when someone is flailing 
> around).
> 
> ken
